addressleaf.section:
To the right honorable S
r
Francis Walsingham knight Principall Secretary to her Ma
tie
.

page.lettertext:
It may please yo
r
H sins I writte my former,
there is a souldier come hither from
Nieumeghen,
who maketh report
at
S
r
Martin Schincke
, im-
mediatly uppon
at overthrowe, w
ch
he gave to
e
Enemie, attempted
e suprpise of Neiumeghen,
where he failed of his purpose, and as
e common
voice went, was drowned in a boate
at soncke
in
e river, being overcharged w
t
e multitude
of those,
at fledde thither for succo
r
. The souldier
being simple, and running hastely from thens, and
in feare, can tell us no certaintie of
e successe of
that exploit, nor of any necessary circ
u
stance. But we
looke every houre, to knowe
e truthe from others, as
in
e meane season,
e newes are most heavily
taken, these contreis being utterly desititute of any
speciall person of Conduct.
From
e Hage.
Au
g
3. 89.
Yo
r
H. most humbly bounden Tho. Bodley
Presently uppon my former writing we
receaved freshe advertisments from
Count Maurice
,
at for certaine Schincke was drowned w
t
some
150 more. He had entered
e towne of Neiumeghen
w
t
200 of his men, by a larger breache w
ch
they had
forced through a grate of
e walle of
e towne, and
possessed
e market place: so as if his other troopes had
folowed, he had bin master of
e towne: but through
e
swiftnes of
e river,
e vehemence of
e winde, and
some unskilfulnes in
e mariners,
ei were caried
soddainly beyonde
e towne, and could not recover
to come to
e rescue: wheruppon Schincke was
driven backe to his boate, whiche was not sufficient for
e
n
o
bers
at pressed into it: of w
ch
some notw
t
standing recovered land by
swimming, but Schincke in his armor had no meanes to save himself.
The custody of his Sconces, and other places are c
o
mitted by
e
Councell
to
e
Baron of Potleds
, a m
a
generally beloved of
e souldiers, and
one
at Schincke honored very muche. As farre as I can learne
o
r
Englishe companies are arrived in safetie to
Tiet,
both horse
and foote, and will marche to Count Maurice,
w
t
to whome my
L. Burgh
is newly come w
t
a company of 180.
